Details:
Taiwan�s night markets are vibrant hubs of street food, shopping, and games. Examples:

Ningxia Night Market (Taipei) � Famous for oyster omelets and peanut ice cream rolls.
Liuhe Night Market (Kaohsiung) � Seafood lovers� paradise.
Fengjia Night Market (Taichung) � One of the largest in Taiwan.

Temples in Taiwan are not only religious centers but also architectural and cultural treasures. They reflect a blend of Taoist, Buddhist, and folk beliefs, often bustling with rituals and festivals. Examples:

Longshan Temple (Taipei) � Historic and ornate, a spiritual heart of the city.
Zhenlan Temple (Dajia, Taichung) � Famous for the Mazu pilgrimage.
Fo Guang Shan (Kaohsiung) � A massive Buddhist complex with a giant Buddha statue.

Taiwan�s natural beauty is showcased in its national parks and hiking trails, ranging from coastal cliffs to alpine forests. These spots are ideal for outdoor enthusiasts and nature lovers.

Examples:

Taroko National Park � Marble gorges and scenic trails.
Yangmingshan National Park � Hot springs and volcanic landscapes near Taipei.
Alishan Forest Railway & Trails � Sunrise views and ancient cypress trees.

Taiwan�s indigenous communities preserve rich traditions, languages, and crafts. Visiting these sites offers insight into the island�s original cultures and their deep connection to nature.

Examples:

Smangus (Hsinchu) � A remote Atayal village known for giant trees and eco-tourism.
Kuban Village (Taitung) � Amis cultural experiences and traditional music.
Wulai (New Taipei) � Accessible Atayal area with hot springs and cultural shows.
A stylish area filled with designer boutiques, indie brands, and cozy caf�s, making it one of Taipei�s favorite spots for young trendsetters.
Known as Taipei�s youth fashion hub, Ximending is packed with trendy shops, street food, and vibrant nightlife. It�s often compared to Tokyo�s Shibuya.
Beyond being a landmark, Taipei 101 hosts luxury brands, international shops, and a world-class shopping experience.
The largest shopping mall in southern Taiwan, featuring fashion, entertainment, and even a rooftop Ferris wheel.
A trendy shopping complex next to the Kaohsiung Arena, offering fashion, lifestyle, and entertainment in one spot.
A beautifully restored historic department store blending old Japanese-era architecture with modern lifestyle shops, perfect for a cultural shopping stroll.
Once a Japanese-era sake distillery, now transformed into a cultural hub filled with art exhibitions, design shops, and trendy caf�s.
A renovated tobacco factory that�s now a hotspot for design markets, exhibitions, and creative events.
A historic hillside settlement turned into an artist village, showcasing contemporary art and experimental creativity.
A vibrant arts district by the harbor, packed with murals, installations, and creative markets.
Famous for its �blueprint� wall art, this area is filled with indie shops, cultural exhibitions, and creative vibes.
European-style museum famed for art, instruments, and natural history.
Upscale club with world-class DJs, light shows, and a stylish party vibe popular among locals and expats.
Trendy cocktail club blending sleek design, creative drinks, and DJ sets�perfect for young trendsetters.
Casual club with mixed music styles, street food nearby, and a welcoming vibe for students and travelers.
Iconic nightclub hosting big EDM parties, light shows, and a lively young crowd.
A speakeasy-style bar in a historic townhouse, recognized in Asia�s 50 Best Bars, offering 300+ whiskies and creative cocktails.
Hidden speakeasy mixing traditional apothecary decor with modern cocktails, loved by locals and tourists.
Taipei�s largest night market, famous for street food, quirky snacks, and fun carnival games � a must-visit for first-timers.
Known for its authentic Taiwanese street food like pepper buns, this lively market offers a more traditional vibe in the city.
A compact yet famous night market offering a curated selection of classic Taiwanese snacks, loved by locals and tourists alike.
Kaohsiung�s iconic night market by the harbor, offering fresh seafood, bubble tea, and a bustling night-time atmosphere.
Popular among locals for late-night eats, carnival games, and a lively street food scene.
A mix of historic streets and night market stalls where you can enjoy Tainan�s famous snacks and local culture.
A quick, easy climb with sweeping Taipei 101 views�perfect for sunset photos.
With only half hour from downtown Taipei by metro, you can see volcanic landscapes (sulfur vents and hot springs...), flower fields and trails for all levels.
A scenic coastal hike with unique rock shapes and breathtaking ocean views.

Take the Maokong Gondola from Taipei Zoo MRT Station up into the hills. The ride offers amazing views of Taipei and the tea-growing region. Walk on the trails to see the old Taiwan farm scenes and taste the tea oil made dishes.
(For advanced hiker) It�s not just one lake but a cluster of about 20 small lakes, often called the �Scattered Pearls� because of their distribution across the forested landscape.
